1596981403_1CpcxT1xWtqTRZTRR1KnH8gGsY2i4.body: It has it's own "DNS" - ZeroName.  See http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Name2NXVi1RDPDgf5617UoW7xA6YrhM9F/  ZeroName gets the names from the NameCoin blockchain.

> [sdfsdgasdew](#comment_64_1CpcxT1xWtqTRZTRR1KnH8gGsY2i4rJ7du): Tell me more detail about it , for example, when I press enter in the browser with the address "http://127.0.0.1:43110/00.00.bit" ,the zeronet client will call Namecoin's server to inquire into the database hold by namecoin.The namecoin server will give string  "15DoUzapXLvwTxmjgSePYKiDWnsev7L4KK" to Zeronet client?Is it the whole process？00.00.bit    15DoUzapXLvwTxmjgSePYKiDWnsev7L4KK    • Namecoin

No it doesn't call the namecoin server.  When you get a .bit domain from namecoin, it registers you in the blockchain.  I believe that what ZeroNet does is keep a current copy of the namecoin blockchain and uses that for lookups.

You can look at the code here (clearnet link) https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/tree/fa7013fdf7eeb7bb01c1c113b4529b7233bf52ce/plugins/Zeroname

There is no "official server".  This is a distributed network.  Most of the questions you're asking I don't think are documented; maybe someone else will chime in if they are.  The best way to proceed I think is to look at the code on github  ZeroNet behaves really differently from the internet, so you need to start thinking along those lines.  The best way to do so, I think, is to look at the source and see what it does.

I can't think of a way to share them.  But maybe the problem is they can't get to the trackers?  It might be a  DNS block in which case if you give them the IP of the trackers they should be able to connect and get peers.

See if using a copy of your ZeroNet\data\trackers.json file works.

> [gomzik](#comment_10_1F6BMqittjWUStzUbRXm2kG2GQ3RdBLqFQ): trackers.json does not changed from fresh install on my pc. I will try, but not sure, that it helps. Thanks.

Oh I thought of something else.  On the PC zeronet will use TOR to connect to some peers (you can also force it to use TOR for everything).  I don't know what is done on Android.  It may be the PC is working because it's using TOR to connect to peers.

[otbtechnologies7]  Good work, friend.  Nice of you to help people.  Do you have thoughts on what I said above about TOR on PC vs Android?

Here are what the default TOR settings look like on PC (sorry for clearnet link):  https://imgur.com/a/zcu4Jv7

If you can't see that I think I can post the pic to my ZeroMe stuff.  Let me know.

It may be that TOR has to be enabled, and maybe tunneling, for it to work.  Since I haven't used the android app, not sure if it can go through TOR itself.

Here I put it on ZeroNet so you should be able to see it no matter what.  http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1RedkCkVaXuVXrqCMpoXQS29bwaqsuFdL/1JKZJh2XYF8C6q5p7T7FmiL3JDux2CxWyJ/1597181358

1597175618_144CwRj8eynTUC9DtGHaNHR3wm9P2.body:
> [otbtechnologies7](#comment_88_1BULx3pdbqxqTWCSBvSQijujiHhXJT1D3w): Well, in any case, there would have to be a server of sorts which would be you. I am not sure I understand the concept. Please elaborate.  [...]

I think he is looking for something to handle stream distribution.  Normally one streams from their PC to like facebook or twitch, and that delivers all the content to multiple peers.  Sounds like he is looking for a distributed replacement for twitch.

I was thinking about this myself a week or so ago and also found no solution, so I'm also interested.

The most I could come up with was have a seedbox that takes a stream, buffers it to a file, and serves out pieces from the buffered file.  But that seems like it would need protocol changes to support.

 I don't know of any clients that support this - they support the client streaming from the torrent, but AFAIK nothing supports the stream feeding the torrent.

If anyone knows, please share!

> [c2vjcmv0](#comment_22_18HDixtzvKVUN5q6DmabhcWQKAP8d9dTd3): A p2p broadcast sounds like an oxymoron. To achieve that you would need multiple p2ps which will increase the bandwidth. That's kinda the reason to why services use broadcasting instead of p2p. Or have I misunderstood the question?

I can't speak for OP, but you understand my thinking.  The reason for it is the same for any distributed stuff - so that the stream can't be taken down by the streaming host.  But I'm thinking more along the lines of a livestream torrent; maybe OP actually means P2P in which case he probably wants something like Tox.

> [c2vjcmv0](#comment_23_18HDixtzvKVUN5q6DmabhcWQKAP8d9dTd3): Then, isn't Tox a valid alternative?

It definitely is if one wants P2P.  I haven't looked at how Tox implements a/v streams for a while, but I think the source of the stream broadcasts directly to all the peers in the Tox room.

What I'm tangentially interested in is being able to stream to a swarm so that the swarm helps distribute it.  I'm not sure if Tox does that.  I don't have a use case in particular but find it an interesting problem.

I don't want to distract from OP.   Tox may very well be the best solution for them, and they may just want to post a Tox key on ZeroNet and use Tox for the actual communications.

OP: If you want to look at tox here is the clearnet site:  https://tox.chat/

This looks interesting as well if one wants to broadcast from a file:

https://github.com/mafintosh/peerflix

1597818504_1GooUE19488nDwG3TdkM8seYAHct4.body: To slow down spammer account creation one possibility is to use proof of work much like bitcoin uses it.  To create a new ID, some problem that takes a long time could need to be solved.  Of course, the determined could set up "id creation farms" that do nothing but generated proof-of-work to obtain a lot of Ids, but it's a step in that direction and doesn't require a central authority to approve the person - just has to validate that the work was done.

> [geekless](#comment_213_1GooUE19488nDwG3TdkM8seYAHct4gjkq4): Without the server side of ZeroID you can't even register an ID and post to this forum.

ZeroID could use blockchain combined with my suggestion below for a proof-of-work to slow down spammers.  If the proof of work passes, one is added to the blockchain.  Unfortunately, that would mean storing a copy of the user id block chain everywhere, but I don't really see a solution - blockchain or not - where a user can be validated without going to a server unless the list of users is replicated everywhere.

> [xcape2net](#comment_779_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): Or, a better system than downloading every email to every peer's hard drive needs to be implemented. What do you think?

We could use a routing system like uucp mail where a mail is routed to the user and only copied to machines along the route.  We would need DHT/PEX, though, so a path could be discovered from point A to point B through peers.  Each peer would try to forward to one peer closer until the node was reached, holding onto the mail until it gave it to another peer or a timer expired, etc.

1599297078_1HMvhRJegHrC92gxZhrPBeATg69tZ.body:
> [kec](#comment_24_1PzqXnnYNvUNj4EjU1X6VCRAGFo7Rk9AWN): Admit it - zeronet is preferred because it has a web gui.

Agree, but I see no problem in that regard.  Usability is important for adoption.

There are different goals with all of those systems, which is part of the problem.  Right now, ZeroNet seems great for distributed sites.   Where ZeroNet is weak is anonymity, large data sets, real-time communictions (e.g., streaming).

That doesn't stop us from combining things, though.   ZeroNet can be the webface, IPFS can be storage, qBitTorrent for streaming, etc.  Why not put them all in one ecosystem?

There's also Ethereum which might be useful for block-chain things.
